questions.text: A patient presents with right lower abdominal pain and loose stools for the past 8 months. He smokes 12 cigarettes per day for the last 10 years. Endoscopy findings are shown below. Identify the correct statement about this condition.

choices.text: Granulomas are seen in the lymph nodes
Lesions are present in a continuous pattern
Inflammation is limited to mucosa and submucosa

questions.solution:
The clinical features of loose stools, right lower quadrant pain, and endoscopy showing cobblestone appearance, with a history of smoking suggest a diagnosis of Crohn's disease (CD). In this condition, granulomas can be seen in the layers of the small bowel, lymph nodes, mesentery, peritoneum, liver, and pancreas.

Microscopically, they are non-caseating granulomas. Other histologic features of CD include submucosal or subserosal lymphoid aggregates, microscopic skip areas, transmural inflammation, etc.

The inflammation in Crohn's disease mainly affects the ileum and colon, while the rectum is often spared. The earliest lesions seen are aphthous ulcers located in the mucosa which then spreads to result in transmural inflammation. There is normal mucosa in between the ulcers (skip lesions) which gives them a cobblestone appearance seen on microscopy. Another finding is the growth of mesenteric fat leading to extensive fat wrapping around the bowel wall which is termed as creeping fat. In addition, Crohn's disease often have adhesions and fistulas.

Other options:

In ulcerative colitis, lesions begin from the dentate line (rectum) and extend proximally. They are continuous lesions. Histologically, the lesions and inflammation are within the lamina propria and limited to the surface epithelium.

questions.text: A young man presented with a growing mass in the neck. It was found to be medullary thyroid carcinoma after workup. Further investigations revealed the presence of pheochromocytoma and parathyroid adenoma. He mentions that his uncle and his grandfather also had some form of cancer. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient has medullary thyroid cancer, along with pheochromocytoma and parathyroid adenoma. He is likely to be suffering from multiple endocrine neoplasia (MEN) 2A.

Multiple endocrine neoplasia is characterized by the presence of tumors in two or more endocrine glands. It can be MEN 1, MEN 2A, MEN 2B (MEN 3), or MEN 4.

MEN 1 is associated mainly with parathyroid adenoma, pancreatic tumors, and pituitary tumors. 

MEN 2A is associated mainly with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, and parathyroid adenoma. 

MEN 2B is associated mainly with medullary thyroid carcinoma, pheochromocytoma, mucosal neuroma, marfanoid habitus, medullated corneal nerve fibers, and megacolon.

MEN 4 is associated with parathyroid adenoma, pituitary adenoma, and reproductive organ tumors.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect regarding subacute thyroiditis?

choices.text: Thyrotoxic phase is followed by hypothyroid phase
Preceded by upper respiratory tract infection
Antithyroid drugs are given in the thyrotoxic phase of the disease

questions.solution:
Antithyroid drugs have no role in the management of the thyrotoxic phase of subacute thyroiditis. 

Subacute thyroiditis is a granulomatous thyroiditis that occurs secondary to viral upper respiratory tract infections. Many viruses such as mumps, influenza, coxsackie, adenoviruses, and echoviruses have been implicated in this condition. This condition is predominantly seen in middle-aged women, and usually resolves without any sequelae.

Patients present with painfully enlarged thyroid gland and fever. Depending on the phase of the illness, it may present with features of thyrotoxicosis or hypothyroidism. The natural history of the disease has three phases:

  • Thyrotoxic phase: there is increased follicular destruction and release of thyroglobulin and thyroid hormones, leading to increased circulating T4 and T3 and suppression of TSH
  • Hypothyroid phase: after some days the thyroid hormone stores are depleted leading to hypothyroidism. This phase is characterized has low free T4 (and sometimes T3) and moderately increased TSH levels.
  • Recovery phase: The thyroid hormones and TSH come to normal levels as the patient completely recovers from the disease.

Subacute thyroiditis is treated with large doses of aspirin or NSAIDs. If there are severe local or systemic systems, then steroids are used. Beta-blockers can be used to treat the symptoms of thyrotoxicosis. In the hypothyroid phase, if the levels of thyroid hormones are too low, then levothyroxine might be required. However, antithyroid drugs are not given in the thyrotoxic phase.

questions.text: A young patient is brought to the emergency room in a comatose state. He weighs around 70 kg. On examination, his serum glucose levels were found to be 500 mg/dL, arterial pH is 7.33, with increased plasma ketone levels. His serum potassium levels are normal. What is the bolus dose of insulin that should be administered immediately to this patient?

choices.text: 7 units of short acting regular insulin intravenously
7 units of short acting insulin subcutaneously
14 units of short acting insulin intravenously
14 units of short acting regular insulin intravenously

questions.solution:
In the above clinical scenario, the patient is likely to have diabetic ketoacidosis (DKA). The dose of insulin that should be immediately administered to this patient is 0.1 units per kg. Since the patient weighs around 70 Kg he should be administered 7 units intravenously.

Diabetic ketoacidosis is an acute complication of type 1 diabetes mellitus. The symptoms include nausea, vomiting, thirst/polyuria, severe abdominal pain, and shortness of breath. It is precipitated by various events like inadequate insulin administration, infection (pneumonia/UTI/ gastroenteritis/sepsis), infarction (cerebral, coronary, mesenteric, peripheral), drugs (cocaine), and pregnancy.

Clinical signs:

  • Kussmaul breathing (deep, rapid breathing)
  • Fruity odor on the patient’s breath (acetone breath)
  • Tachycardia
  • Dehydration
  • Hypotension

Blood parameters:

  • Hyperglycemia – 250–600 mg%
  • Pseudohyponatremia - there is a 1.6-mmol/L reduction in serum sodium level for each 5.6-mmol/L rise in the serum glucose level.
  • Overall total body K+ deficit, however, the serum K+ at presentation may be mildly elevated, secondary to the acidosis.
  • Osmolality – 300–320 mOsm/kg
  • Plasma ketones – positive
  • Metabolic acidosis – increased anion gap (HAGMA)
  • Serum bicarbonate <15 meq/L – best initial investigation
  • Hypertriglyceridemia
  • Hyperamylasemia

The algorithm for the management of DKA is shown below.

questions.text:
An intern is asked to insert Ryle's tube in a young patient. He performs the following steps.

He made the patient sit in the upright position and assessed for the nasal septal deviation. He instructed the patient to sniff and swallow 2% viscous lignocaine. Estimation of the length of insertion was done by measuring the distance from the tip of the nose, around the ear, and down to the xiphisternum. He inserted a 16 Fr NG tube in the more blocked nose so as to allow maximal breathing in the patient. At last, he confirmed the proper placement of the NG tube by aspirating the gastric contents. 

Comment about the above procedure:

choices.text: The intern has used correct method for anesthetising the patient before procedure
Length of insertion is measured by the distance from the tip of the nose, jaw, and to xiphisternum.
The size of the nasogastric tube is too small in the above scenario
Inserting the nasogastric tube in more blocked nose is correct

questions.solution:
The intern has instructed the patient to sniff and swallow 2% viscous lignocaine. This is the correct method of anaesthetising the patient before the procedure.

Indications of nasogastric (NG) tube insertion

Diagnostic indications for NG intubation include the following:

  • Evaluation of upper gastrointestinal (GI) bleeding (ie, presence, volume)
  • Aspiration of gastric fluid content
  • Identification of the esophagus and stomach on a chest radiograph
  • Administration of radiographic contrast to the GI tract 

Therapeutic indications for NG intubation include the following:

  • Gastric decompression
  • Relief of symptoms and bowel rest in the setting of small-bowel obstruction
  • Aspiration of gastric content from recent ingestion of toxic material
  • Administration of medication
  • Feeding
  • Bowel irrigation
  • NG tube can be kept following corrosive ingestion for the development of a tract in the esophagus that subsequently can be used for balloon dilatation

The procedure of nasogastric tube insertion

  • Explain the procedure of the nasogastric tube insertion to the patient and the patient attenders.
  • Examine the patient's nostril for any blockade and septal deviation. Ask him to close each nostril and breathe. The tube has to be inserted in the more patent nostril.
  • Tilt the head of the patient backwards and ask him to slowly sniff and swallow 2% lidocaine. Wait for 5-10 minutes for the anesthesia to act.
  • Estimate the length of insertion by measuring the distance from the tip of the nose, around the ear, and up to the xiphisternum. 
  • Position the patient sitting upright with the neck partially flexed. Ask the patient to hold the cup of water in his or her hand and put the straw in his or her mouth. Lubricate the distal tip of the NG tube.
  • Now gently insert the tube into the nose. 16-18 Fr tube is commonly used in adults. When the tube reaches the nasopharynx, there is a resistance felt. Ask the patient to swallow water through a straw. 
  • Continue to advance the NG tube until the distance of the estimated length is reached.

 Confirmation of the correct position is done by the following:

  • Auscultation in the epigastric area while injecting a bolus of air
  • Aspiration of gastric contents
  • Chest radiograph
  • Colorimetric capnography

questions.text: A surgical resident got his skin cut with a knife while he was operating on a patient diagnosed with hepatitis B infection. His anti-HBs levels were 45 mlU/ml. What will you do next?

choices.text: Give hepatitis B hyperimmune globulin and start hepatitis B vaccination

questions.solution:
In this scenario, since the anti-HBs antibodies titer in the resident is more than 10 mIU/ml, he would not need any further prophylaxis.

Post-exposure prophylaxis of Hepatitis B:

Scenario 1- The source is HBsAg negative

  • If the healthcare worker is not vaccinated- Initiate vaccination in the healthcare worker
  • If the healthcare worker is already vaccinated- No need for any action

Scenario 2- The source is HBsAg positive

  • If the healthcare worker is not vaccinated- Administer hepatitis B hyperimmune globulin (HBIG) single-dose and initiate vaccination. 
  • If the healthcare worker is vaccinated- Measure the anti-HBs antibody titers in him. If the levels are more than 10 mIU/ml, no further prophylaxis is required.
    • If the levels are less than 10mIU/mL, then administer HBIG single dose and reinitiate vaccination.
    • If the levels are less than 10mIU/mL, even after two complete series of vaccination- Give two doses of HBIG one month apart.

questions.text: A young woman visits the doctor because she has stiffness in her wrist and small joints of the hand. It is more in the early morning and improves with physical activity. On examination, swelling and pain are noted in the wrists, metacarpophalangeal joints, and proximal interphalangeal joints. Laboratory investigations reveal high titers of anti-CCP antibodies. Which of the following is the most common pulmonary manifestation of this disease?
questions.solution:
The clinical features are suggestive of rheumatoid arthritis. The most common pulmonary manifestation of this disease is Pleuritis. Clinical features of rheumatoid arthritis:

Joints: Patients have early morning stiffness of joints of the hand. This stiffness persists for around 1 hour and improves with physical activity. The most commonly involved joints are wrists, metacarpophalangeal (MCP), and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. Chronic progressive destruction of the joint leads to deformities.

  • Ulnar deviation: Results from subluxation of the MCP joints, with subluxation, or partial dislocation, of the proximal phalanx to the volar side of the hand.
  • Swan-neck deformity: Hyperextension of the PIP joint with flexion of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. 
  • Boutonnière deformity: Flexion of the PIP joint with hyperextension of the DIP joint
  • Z-line deformity: Subluxation of the first MCP joint with hyperextension of the first interphalangeal (IP) joint

Extra-articular features:

Skin: Firm and non-tender nodules that are adherent to the periosteum, tendons, or bursae

Pulmonary: Pleuritis is the most common pulmonary manifestation seen in Rheumatoid arthritis. Usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP), a type of ILD is seen more commonly in males and smokers.

Cardiac: It can cause pericarditis, cardiomyopathy, mitral regurgitation, etc.

Rheumatoid:vasculitis presents as petechiae, purpura, digital infarcts, gangrene, livedo reticularis

Hematological: Normochromic normocytic anemia

Rheumatoid arthritis disease is commonly associated with coronary artery disease, carotid atherosclerosis, osteoporosis, and hypoandrogenism.

1) NSAIDs - analgesic and anti-inflammatory, used as adjunctive for management of uncontrollable symptoms and in acute flares.

2) Glucocorticoids - used in acute flare for rapid control and as initial therapy before the onset of action of DMARDs. Chronic administration of low doses is needed in patients with inadequate response to DMARDs.

  • Prednisolone - oral

  • Triamcinolone - intraarticular
     

3) DMARDs - disease-modifying anti-rheumatoid drugs:

 

- Conventional DMARDs:

  • Methotrexate (MTX)- is an antifolate drug. The DMARD of choice and the anchor drug for combination therapy. Regular LFT monitoring is required.
  • Hydroxychloroquine- is used as monotherapy for early and mild disease and in combination with other DMARDs for severe cases.
  • Sulfasalazine- is a salicylate. It reduces the radiographic progression of the disease.
  • Leflunomide- is a pyrimidine synthase inhibitor used as an alternative to MTX.

- Biologicals:

  • TNF-α antagonists- used in combination with MTX. Has a risk of serious bacterial infections, opportunistic fungal infection & reactivation of latent TB. The TNF-α inhibitors are adalimumab, golimumab, etanercept, infliximab, and certolizumab.
  • Abatacept- a T-cell costimulation inhibitor, used in combination with MTX, leflunomide, etc.
  • Rituximab- an anti-CD20 antibody. Used in refractory disease in combination with MTX.
  • Anakinra- an IL-1 receptor antagonist. It should not be combined with anti-TNF alpha.
  • IL-6 receptor antagonists- tocilizumab and sarilumab are used as monotherapy or combination therapy in moderate to severe disease.  

- Small molecules: 

  • Janus kinase inhibitors: Tofacitinib, baricitinib, and upadacitinib are used as monotherapy or combination therapy.

questions.text:
A 69-year-old woman presents to her primary care physician complaining of fatigue and achiness in her shoulders and hips. Her whole body feels stiff in the morning for at least 60- 90 minutes. She also complains of severe headaches and pain in the scalp and jaw. On physical examination, she has decreased the active range of motion of her shoulders and hips. She has no muscle tenderness. Strength is 5/5 in all four extremities. Neurologic examination is insignificant.

Laboratory tests show:
WBC count: 8600/mm³
Hemoglobin: 10.4 g/dL
Platelet count: 3,00,000/mm³
Erythrocyte sedimentation rate: 120 mm/hr
Creatine kinase levels- Normal
A short course of prednisone leads to an almost complete resolution of symptoms. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The patient in this scenario is an elderly woman and complains of stiffness in her shoulders and hips. This symptom is associated with headache, anemia, elevated ESR, and a very good response to prednisone. These suggest that the patient has polymyalgia rheumatica.

Polymyalgia rheumatica is characterized by stiffness and pain in the muscles of the neck, shoulder, back, hips, and thigh. The stiffness is usually in the early morning and lasts for at least 1 hour. It can occur in isolation or can also occur along with giant cell arteritis.

Giant cell arteritis is the inflammation of the medium to large-sized arteries. It commonly involves the temporal artery. The disease is commonly seen in females over 50 years of age. It is characterized by fever, anemia, and headache. Depending on the artery involved, the patient may have tenderness over the affected artery, scalp pain, jaw and tongue claudication.

Laboratory investigations reveal elevated ESR and normochromic normocytic anemia. It is confirmed by temporal artery biopsy.

The patients have a good response to glucocorticoid therapy. Glucocorticoids should be started as soon as the disease is suspected in order to prevent visual loss. Untreated patients may develop ischemic optic neuropathy.

Other options

Option A- Rheumatoid arthritis is usually seen in females between 25-55 years of age. The most common joints involved are the wrists, metacarpophalangeal (MCP), and proximal interphalangeal (PIP) joints. 

Option B- Patients with fibromyalgia complain of diffuse musculoskeletal pain. The pain is poorly localized. Physical examination typically reveals muscle tenderness. Routine laboratory tests appear normal.

Option C- Polymyositis presents with symmetric and proximal muscle weakness that worsens over several weeks to months. There may be associated heart, lung, and joint involvement as well. Creatine kinase levels are always elevated

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman presents with severe joint pains for 1 month. She also says her skin feels firm and tight for the past 6 months and progressed rapidly since then. Further history taking reveals features of mild Raynaud's syndrome since 6 months. On examination, the skin over the fingers, legs, arms, and trunk appear firm and indurated on palpation. Which of the following antibodies will most likely be elevated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of severe arthralgia and diffuse involvement of the skin with rapid progression, along with a recent history of Raynaud's phenomenon, is suggestive of diffuse systemic sclerosis. Anti–topoisomerase I antibody is most likely to be elevated in this patient.

Reasons why this cannot be limited systemic sclerosis:

  • The onset of Raynaud's syndrome coincides with the onset of skin symptoms, whereas in limited systemic sclerosis, it precedes skin symptoms and has a history of over a decade.

Systemic sclerosis is a chronic and progressive disease that involves sclerosis of the skin and the organs. It can be divided into limited cutaneous systemic sclerosis (lcSSc) and diffuse cutaneous systemic sclerosis (dcSSC) depending on the extent of skin involvement.

In lcSSc, the skin involvement has a slow progression and is limited to fingers, distal to elbows, face. This disease has a slow progression. On the contrary, in dcSSc, the skin involvement is early and rapid. It can involve fingers, extremities, face, and trunk. They also have severe joint pains and musculoskeletal involvement.

questions.text: A 23-year-old man presented with diarrhea, floating stools, and weight loss for 3 months. The biopsy of the intestine is shown below. His symptoms improved with folic acid intake. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario of a young man presenting with diarrhea, floating stools, and weight loss with histopathology showing partial villous atrophy and marked intraepithelial lymphocytosis indicating inflammation of lamina propria and improvement with folic acid intake is suggestive of tropical sprue.

Tropical sprue is an acquired malabsorptive condition that causes chronic diarrhea, steatorrhea, weight loss, and folate and vitamin B12 malabsorption. It occurs in some tropical regions and is often considered a postinfectious complication. Diagnosis is based on a small intestinal biopsy showing villous atrophy and chronic inflammation, similar to celiac disease. However, tropical sprue is unresponsive to a gluten-free diet.

Treatment includes broad-spectrum antibiotics (e.g., tetracycline for up to six months) and folic acid supplementation, which can lead to improvement within weeks. Patients often recover fully if they leave the endemic area. Folic acid alone can improve symptoms and correct hematologic deficiencies, but antibiotics are typically needed for complete resolution.

Other options:

Option A: Celiac disease is a gluten-sensitive enteropathy. Patients present with iron deficiency anemia, weight loss, diarrhea, and malabsorption. A biopsy reveals blunting of the villi, crypt hyperplasia, and inflammation propria. Tissue transglutaminase is involved in the pathogenesis of this disorder. Patients respond to a gluten-free diet. The image below shows histopathological findings seen in celiac disease.

Option B: Whipple's disease is a multiorgan disease caused by the bacteria Tropheryma whipplei. It is characterized by arthralgia, arthritis, weight loss, diarrhea, abdominal pain, and psychiatric manifestations. The organism can be detected by tissue immunohistochemistry and tissue staining for PAS-positive macrophages. The below image shows the PAS stain in Whipple's disease.

Option D: Short bowel syndrome is characterized by extensive removal of the small intestine. The loss of small-bowel surface area leads to severe diarrhea, weight loss, and problems absorbing fat, protein, and carbohydrates.

questions.text: A 70-year-old woman was brought with complaints of progressive memory loss that began three years back. She recently forgot her way back home while returning from a market. There is no history of personality changes, rigidity, or gait disturbances. Which of the following is not a risk factor for the development of this disease?

choices.text: Use of non steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs
E4 allele of Apo E gene

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario of progressive memory loss in an elderly woman, without any associated symptoms, is suggestive of Alzheimer’s disease (AD). The use of non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAID) is not a risk factor for this disease.

Alzheimer's disease is a condition characterized by progressive deterioration of memory. It is the most common cause of dementia in the elderly.

The risk factors include:

  • Age >70 years and female gender
  • Positive family history and Apo ε4 allele
  • Diabetes, hypertension, elevated levels of homocysteine and cholesterol 
  • Diminished intake of folic acid, fruits, vegetables, red wine, and low levels of exercise
  • Down's syndrome.

Use of NSAIDs has been shown to be protective against AD.

Pathology shows the presence of neuritic plaques and neurofibrillary tangles. A central core of amyloid, proteoglycans, ApoE, α-antichymotrypsin, and other proteins form the neuritic plaques while neurofibrillary tangles are composed of silver-staining neuronal cytoplasmic fibrils made of abnormally phosphorylated tau proteins. 

Patients may have the following features

  • Memory impairment gets unrecognized in the early stages. Eventually, interference with daily activities like difficulty in keeping track of finances, driving, shopping, and housekeeping may be seen. In severe impairment, the patient easily gets lost and confused.
  • Language deficits appear as impairment in naming followed by comprehension and fluency.
  • Patients have difficulty dressing, eating, copying geometric figures, and reading the clock due to their visuospatial deficits.

It is treated with cholinesterase inhibitors like donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine, and NMDA receptor antagonist like memantine.

Related Pearl: Alzheimer’s disease

Alzheimer’s disease:

  • Age of onset > 60 years
  • Mini-mental state examination (MMSE) < 24
  • Diagnosis: Clinical

    • Progressive worsening of memory and other cognitive function
    • No disturbance in consciousness
    • Other systemic causes must be ruled out

  • Other risk factors – Family history, presenilin-1, presenilin-2, Apolipoprotein E4 (ApoE ε4 allele), Ubiquitin, Down syndrome and smoking.

Protective factors: NSAIDs and Apolipoprotein E2

Causes: Decrease in acetylcholine causing depletion of the cholinergic neurons in the nucleus basalis of Meynert resulting in short-term memory defects. 

Early findings:

  • Anterograde memory loss (immediate recall affected, distant memories preserved)
  • Visuospatial deficits (lost in own neighborhood)
  • Language difficulties (difficulty finding words)
  • Cognitive impairment with a progressive decline
  • Anosognosia 
  • Visual processing dysfunction (posterior cortical atrophy syndrome)
  • Difficulties with naming and repetition (logopenic aphasia)

Late findings:

  • Psychotic symptoms: delusions
  • Apraxia: Difficulty to perform learned motor tasks
  • Lack of insight regarding deficits
  • Non-cognitive neurologic deficits: Pyramidal and extrapyramidal, myoclonus and seizures
  • disrupted sleep - wake pattern.
  • Urinary incontinence.
  • Loss of procedural memory

Histopathology:

  • Senile plaques (amyloid deposits), neurofibrillary tangles (composed of tau proteins), neuronal loss, synaptic loss, and granulovacuolar degeneration of neurons.

The image below shows neurofibrillary tangles in Alzheimer's disease.

  • Cholinesterase inhibitors: donepezil, galantamine, rivastigmine.
  • Monoclonal antibodies against the N-terminus of the Aβ peptide - lecanemab, donanemab

questions.text: An IT professional was found to have vitamin D deficiency during a routine health check-up. He purchased vitamin D 60,000 IU sachets over-the-counter and started consuming them every day. After two weeks, he presented with severe colicky pain over the renal angle. His vitamin D levels are found to be elevated (170 ng/mL). Which of the following medications will be helpful in treating this condition?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario depicts vitamin D toxicity, which has led to hypercalcemia and renal stones. Among the given options, calcitonin can be used for the treatment of this condition.

Vitamin D toxicity occurs due to excessive intake of vitamin D supplements, usually in amounts of >40,000–100,000 IU/day. The symptoms are mainly due to hypercalcemia. Laboratory investigations will show elevated serum vitamin D levels (>100 ng/mL) and calcium.

In such patients, vitamin D supplements should be discontinued immediately, along with restricted exposure to the sun and avoiding calcium supplements. Since vitamin D is stored in the body for a long time, the symptoms may persist for some days even after stopping the intake.

Calcitonin and bisphosphonates are used in cases of severe toxicity causing hypercalcemia. Some patients might require glucocorticoids, which lower plasma calcium levels by reducing calcium absorption from the intestines and increasing its urinary excretion.

questions.text: A young man is brought to the ER with weakness in both legs since yesterday. The weakness has progressed to his arms now and he is having difficulty in breathing. He had an episode of diarrhea 2 weeks ago. Physical examination shows flaccid paralysis in all four limbs and arreflexia. CSF examination shows elevated protein levels but normal cell count. What is the further management for this patient?
questions.solution:
The presence of ascending, flaccid type of paralysis following an episode of diarrhea 2 weeks ago, and CSF examination showing increased protein with normal cell count, point to a diagnosis of Guillain-Barré syndrome (GBS). 

Guillian-Barré syndrome (GBS) is an acute, autoimmune polyneuropathy. The possible antecedent events include respiratory or gastrointestinal infections. The implicated organisms include Campylobacter jejuni, CMV, EBV, and Mycoplasma pneumonia.

The usual presentation is symmetrical, ascending paralysis evolving over hours to a few days. The legs are usually more affected than the arms. Lower cranial nerves are also frequently involved, causing bulbar weakness and difficulty in maintaining an airway and handling secretions. Almost one-third of the patients require mechanical ventilation due to weakness of the respiratory muscles. Deep tendon reflexes also attenuate or disappear within a few days of onset. 

Sensations carried by large myelinated fibers like deep tendon reflexes and proprioception are also affected. Pain and temperature sensations are relatively preserved. Autonomic involvement usually presents with loss of vasomotor control with wide fluctuations in blood pressure and postural hypotension. Fever and constitutional symptoms are absent at the onset of the weakness. Similarly, bladder dysfunction occurs only in severe GBS and is transient. Prominent bladder dysfunction occurring early in the disease course goes against the diagnosis of GBS. 

The patient is likely to have clinical worsening during the first four weeks following the onset of weakness. After this, there's a plateauing of the symptoms and any further deterioration is unlikely.

The treatment for GBS should be initiated as early as possible. High-dose intravenous immune globulin (IVIg) or plasmapheresis can be used for the treatment. A sequential combination of the two has not been found to be more effective than either of them alone. Corticosteroids (option A) are not effective in the treatment of GBS.

The following sequence of events, takes into consideration, the development of Guillain-Barre syndrome (GBS) associated with Campylobacter jejuni infection.

  1. B cells recognize glycoconjugates on jejuni (Cj) that cross-react with ganglioside present on Schwann cell surface and subjacent peripheral nerve myelin.

  3. The activated B cells escape from Peyer’s patches into regional lymph nodes.
  4. Activated T cells also function to assist in the opening of the blood-nerve barrier, facilitating penetration of pathogenic autoantibodies.
  5. The earliest changes in myelin consist of edema between myelin lamellae and vesicular disruption of the outermost myelin layers.
  6. These effects are associated with activation of the C5b-C9 membrane attack complex and mediated by calcium entry; it is possible that the macrophage cytokine tumor necrosis factor (TNF) also participates in myelin damage.

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with hemoptysis, red-colored urine, and frequent sinusitis. Her blood reports revealed anemia, leucocytosis, and elevated erythrocyte sedimentation rate. Serology is positive for antiproteinase-3 ANCA. Her chest x-ray is given below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
This patient has the involvement of the upper respiratory tract (frequent sinusitis), lower respiratory tract (hemoptysis), and kidneys (hematuria), and an x-ray shows the presence of a cavity in the right lung. These, along with laboratory features and positivity for antiproteinase-3 ANCA (cANCA) suggest that the most likely diagnosis is granulomatosis with polyangiitis (GPA).

GPA is a type of vasculitis characterized by necrotizing granulomas in the upper and lower respiratory tract, and small and medium vessels. Also, necrotizing crescentic glomerulonephritis is present in the condition.

Clinically, they present with fever, purulent rhinorrhea, nasal ulcers, sinus pain, saddle nose, polyarthralgia, cough, hemoptysis, breathlessness, hematuria, and proteinuria. Occasionally, cutaneous purpura and mononeuritis complex may be present.

Antiproteinase 3-ANCA or antineutrophilic cytoplasmic antibody (cANCA) is seen in 95% of patients and is a useful marker of disease activity.

Management is as follows:

  • Induction with cyclophosphamide and glucocorticoids for severe disease. This is stopped after 3-6 months and can be switched to rituximab, azathioprine, methotrexate, and mycophenolate mofetil for the remission.
  • Induction with rituximab and glucocorticoids is also effective in severe disease.
  • For a non-severe disease, methotrexate or mycophenolate mofetil along with glucocorticoids is effective for induction as well as remission.

Other options:

Options A - In Goodpasture's syndrome (pulmonary-renal syndrome), anti-GBM autoantibodies are formed against the glomerular basement membrane. Younger patients present with hemoptysis, fever, dyspnea, and hematuria while older people present with isolated glomerulonephritis.

Option B - Microscopic polyangiitis mainly involves the small arterioles and venules. The presentation is similar to GPA. However, they do not have upper airway disease or pulmonary nodules. They have mainly MPO antibodies or P-ANCA positivity. The distinction can be made on a biopsy where microscopic polyangiitis would have vasculitis without granulomas. 

Option C - Henoch-Schonlein purpura is a small vessel vasculitis that has palpable purpura over the buttocks and lower extremities, arthralgia, gastrointestinal symptoms, and glomerulonephritis. It is commonly seen in children and the mechanism is immune complex deposition with IgA antibody.

questions.text: A middle-aged man noticed that his shoes no longer fit him, his finger ring is getting tighter, and his jaw seems protruded. The image below compares the size of his hand (right side) with that of the physician (left side). MRI of the brain shows a mass in the pituitary gland. Which of the following is not useful in the management of this condition?
questions.solution:
The clinical features and the image are suggestive of acromegaly which can be managed by stereotactic ablation, pegvisomant and transsphenoidal tumor resection.

It is commonly caused due to growth hormone-secreting somatotroph adenoma. Increased secretion of growth hormone (GH) and insulin-like growth factor- 1 (IGF-1) results in acral bone overgrowth. Patients present with frontal bossing, increased hand and foot size, mandibular enlargement with prognathism, and widened space between the lower incisor teeth. Soft tissue swelling results in increased heel pad thickness, increased shoe size, ring tightening, characteristic coarse facial features, and a large fleshy nose.

Other manifestations seen in GH excess are cardiomyopathy, left ventricular hypertrophy, obstructive sleep apnea, diabetes mellitus, etc.

Serum IGF-1 levels and GH suppression test with oral glucose are useful in the diagnosis. The levels of GH do not reduce in response to the oral glucose load. 

GH-secreting adenomas are managed with surgery. Transsphenoidal surgical treatment is the preferred surgery. Stereotactic ablation of GH-secreting adenomas by gamma-knife radiotherapy has also been beneficial. Preoperatively, somatostatin analogs like octreotide and lanreotide are used to shrink the size of the tumor. Another drug that is useful in acromegaly is pegvisomant. It is a growth hormone receptor antagonist and, therefore, antagonizes the actions of GH.

Other options:

Option C: Oglcegepant is a calcitonin gene-related peptide (CGRP) antagonist. It is used for the treatment of migraine.

Related Pearl: Tests for Acromegaly

Screening test:

The single best test for the diagnosis of acromegaly is the measurement of serum insulin-like growth factor-1 (IGF-1). A normal serum IGF-1 concentration is strong evidence that the patient does not have acromegaly.

Confirmatory test:

GH suppression test: 75 g of oral glucose (OGTT- oral glucose tolerance test) is administered to the patient. Blood GH levels are checked at 30, 60, 90, 120 min (i.e over 2 hours) after the glucose load. Normally, glucose suppresses GH and it falls to <1 ng/mL. If GH >1 ng/mL, it is diagnostic of acromegaly.

questions.text: A 35-year-old man with no comorbidities presents with altered sensorium, severe headache, and 2 episodes of vomiting. Lumbar puncture reveals an elevated opening pressure and turbid cerebrospinal fluid, which is sent for analysis. Initial results revealed raised neutrophils. What medications should be started until the final reports are available?
questions.solution:
The clinical features suggest meningitis; given the patient's age and absence of comorbidities, empirical therapy with ceftriaxone and vancomycin should be initiated.

The patient has elevated intracranial pressure with nuchal rigidity, and positive Kernig's (pain on passive extension of the knee when the thigh is flexed on the abdomen) and Brudzinski's (spontaneous flexion of hips and knees on passive flexion of neck) signs. The cerebrospinal fluid (CSF) appears turbid. All these findings are suggestive of bacterial meningitis. The most common organism causing bacterial meningitis in adults is Streptococcus pneumoniae. Other less common causes are Neisseria meningitidis, Staphylococcus aureus, Listeria monocytogenes, Haemophilus sp., and Enterobacteriaceae, etc.

Patients may have a fever, headache, nuchal rigidity, and seizures. Signs of meningeal irritation can be elicited by Kernig's and Brudzinki's signs.

questions.text: An elderly man presents with weakness in his right arm and leg for the past 3 hours with a deviation of mouth to the left side. Non-contrast CT is normal. Which of the following medications is not useful in the management of this patient?
questions.solution:
Sudden onset hemiparesis and facial palsy with apparently normal CT points to ischemic stroke in this patient. Tranexamic acid is not useful for managing this patient with ischemic stroke as it is an anti-fibrinolytic agent used to arrest bleeding and it can cause thromboembolic events. 

Non-contrast CT is the imaging modality of choice in patients with acute stroke. CT may appear normal for the first few hours and the infarct may not appear until 24-48 hours. Diffusion-weighted MRI is more sensitive to detect early brain infarction. 

Initial treatment of acute ischemic stroke includes maintaining the patient's airway, breathing, and circulation. Complications such as hyperglycemia, hypoglycemia, or fever should be treated if present.

Serum glucose should be maintained between 60 mg/dL and 180 mg/dL. Reduction of blood pressure is suggested if >220/120 mmHg, presence of malignant hypertension or concomitant myocardial ischemia, or if blood pressure is >185/110 mmHg in a patient planned for intravenous thrombolysis.

Intravenous thrombolysis with recombinant tissue plasminogen activator (rTPA), alteplase (dose 0.9 mg/kg ) should be immediately administered to patients with ischemic stroke who arrive in the window period within 4.5 hours of symptom onset. 

Oral aspirin is recommended for the acute treatment of ischemic stroke.

IV Mannitol by raising the serum osmolarity is used to prevent the development of cerebral edema.

Endovascular mechanical thrombectomy is done in patients who do not respond to thrombolytic therapy or in whom thrombolysis is contraindicated.

Related Pearl: Indications and Contraindications of thrombolysis in Ischemic Stroke

Indications for thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Clinical diagnosis of stroke
  • Onset of symptoms to time of drug administration <3 hours/4.5 hours
  • Age ≥ 18 years
  • CT scan showing no haemorrhage or edema of >1/3rd of the MCA territory 

Contraindications of thrombolysis in stroke 

  • Sustained BP >185/110 mmHg despite treatment
  • Bleeding diathesis
  • Recent head injury or Intracerebral hemorrhage
  • Major surgery in preceding 14 days
  • Minor stroke symptoms
  • Gastrointestinal bleeding in preceding 21 days
  • Recent myocardial infarction

questions.text: A middle-aged woman presents with excruciating pain in her lips, gums, and cheeks for the past 6 months. The pain is usually triggered by talking and brushing her teeth. Each pain episode lasts for 1-2 minutes. On examination, there is no sensory loss over the face. Which of the following is the first-line management of this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of trigeminal neuralgia. The first-line management of this patient is carbamazepine.

Trigeminal neuralgia is a condition characterized by excruciating paroxysmal pain in the lips, gums, cheek, or chin and, rarely ophthalmic division of the trigeminal nerve. It is also known as tic douloureux (a painful condition of the face). It is commonly seen in middle-aged and elderly women. 

The large myelinated fibers of the trigeminal nerve carry tactile stimuli from the face and do not carry pain fibers themselves. In trigeminal neuralgia, due to compression or other pathologies, the large fibers undergo demyelination. These demyelinated large fibers become hyperexcitable and electrically coupled with the surrounding smaller unmyelinated pain fibers of the trigeminal nerve. This explains why tactile stimulation of trigger zones (lips, gums, cheek, or chin) leads to pain paroxysms. Symptoms occur due to ectopic generation of action potentials in pain-sensitive afferent fibers of the trigeminal nerve root just before entering the pons.

The pain may occur spontaneously or after movements like chewing, speaking, smiling, washing the face, brushing teeth, or exposure to wind. On examination, the physician will not find any sensory loss over the area. The pain usually lasts for seconds or minutes. The intensity of pain is severe, so much so that the patient winces. Therefore it is called a 'tic'.

Carbamazepine is the first-line drug in the management of patients with trigeminal neuralgia. Lamotrigine, Phenytoin, Topiramate, or Gabapentin are other options that may be tried if Carbamazepine is ineffective. Microvascular decompression of the trigeminal nerve can be done if medical therapies fail.

Differential diagnoses of trigeminal neuralgia include:

  • Migraine and cluster headaches - They tend to have deep-seated and continuous pain while trigeminal neuralgia has more of a superficial stabbing quality pain and is episodic. 
  • Short-lasting unilateral headache with conjunctival tearing (SUNCT) - It will typically present with unilateral conjunctival congestion, tearing, and nasal stuffiness. 
  • Temporal arteritis - It will usually be accompanied by myalgias and signs of systemic inflammation. ESR and CRP will be elevated.
  • If trigeminal neuralgia develops in a young patient or is bilateral, a diagnosis of multiple sclerosis should be considered. In such cases, the cause of the pain is a demyelinating plaque near the entry point of the trigeminal nerve in the pons.

questions.text: A patient has developed confusion and keeps bumping into objects. He can speak fluently. But on examination, he cannot differentiate between fingers and cannot write. He also gets confused with the examiner's right and left sides. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis for this patient is Gerstmann syndrome. It is commonly associated with damage to the left (dominant) inferior parietal lobule.

Gerstmann syndrome consists of:

  • Acalculia - impairment of simple arithmetic
  • Dysgraphia - impaired writing
  • Finger anomia - an inability to name individual fingers 
  • Right-left confusion - an inability to tell whether a hand, foot, or arm of the patient or examiner is on the right or left side of the body

Option D: Dejerine-Roussy syndrome is associated with hemisensory loss and severe burning pain in the affected region. It is also known as thalamic pain syndrome.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient presented with pain and swelling in the knee joint. The physician advised for the examination of synovial fluid from the knee joint on polarized light microscopy, which showed needle-shaped crystals. What is the composition and birefringence pattern shown by these crystals?

choices.text: Monosodium urate crystals with negative birefringence
Calcium pyrophosphate crystals with negative birefringence
Calcium oxalate crystals with positive birefringence

questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the presence of needle-shaped crystals in synovial fluid point towards the diagnosis of gouty arthritis. It is caused by the deposition of monosodium urate crystals (MSU), which are needle-shaped and show negative birefringence on polarized light microscopy.

The below image shows negative birefringent needle-shaped crystals seen in gout.

Other options:

Option A- Calcium apatite crystals can occur in areas of tissue damage (dystrophic calcification) and in hypercalcemic or hyperparathyroid states (metastatic calcification). Clumps of these crystals may appear as intra- or extracellular nonbirefringent globules or aggregates that stain purplish with Wright’s stain and bright red with alizarin red S.

Option C- Calcium pyrophosphate crystals (rhomboid-shaped) deposition is seen in pseudogout. These crystals are rod-shaped or rhomboid-shaped and are weakly positive or nonbirefringent crystals.

Option D- Calcium oxalate crystals (CaOx) are seen in chronic renal failure. These crystals can be deposited in visceral organs, blood vessels, bones, and joints. The synovial fluid analysis will show the presence of variable-shaped crystals (commonly bipyramidal crystals are seen) with variable birefringence to polarized light.

NOTE:

Though pseudogout is the condition in which the knee joint is most commonly involved, gout can also involve the knee joint.

Below image shows the crystals seen in pseudogout.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman with a history of multiple sclerosis comes to the hospital. She complains of blurring of vision in one of the eyes soon after she comes home after her zumba classes. What is the name of this sign?
questions.solution:
The blurring of vision after a physical exercise in multiple sclerosis is Uhthoff's Phenomenon. 

Uhthoff ’s phenomenon refers to the unilateral visual blurring that may occur during a hot shower or with physical exercise. It is an exacerbation of the symptoms of multiple sclerosis due to heat.

Other options:

Option A: Lhermitte's sign is an electric shock-like sensation radiating down the back into the legs. It is induced typically by flexion or other movements of the neck. Lhermitte’s sign can also occur simultaneously with other disorders of the cervical spinal cord like cervical spondylosis.

Option C: Facial myokymia is a persistent, rapid flickering contraction of the facial musculature or a contraction that slowly spreads across the face. It results from lesions of the corticobulbar tracts or in the course of the facial nerve in the brainstem.

Option D: Tic douloureux is the other name for trigeminal neuralgia. It can occur when the demyelinating lesion involves the root entry (or exit) of the fifth cranial nerve.

questions.text: A 30-year-old male who is a known case of ulcerative colitis presents with exacerbation of symptoms. His stool frequency suddenly increased to 10-12 times in the past 24 hours, with blood in stools. Investigations revealed a CRP of 60 mg/L. Which of the following is used to define the severity of this disease?
questions.solution:
In the given clinical scenario, the patient presented with acute severe ulcerative colitis. Truelove-Witts criteria is used to define acute severe colitis.

Truelove-Witts criteria define acute severe colitis as the presence of:

  1. ≥ 6 bloody stools/24 hrs
  2. Plus, one or more of the following features suggestive of systemic toxicity:
    • Anemia (Hemoglobin <10 g/dL).
    • Mild fever (>100.04°F).
    • Tachycardia (Pulse ≥90 beats/min).
    • High inflammatory markers (ESR > 30 mm/hr or CRP >30 mg/L).

Other options :

Option B: The 2017 revised McDonald’s criteria is used in the diagnosis of multiple sclerosis. It takes into consideration the clinical attacks and objective lesions. In addition, it also involves the assessment of the lesions based on MRI and other imaging techniques.

Option C: The Montreal classification is used for classifying Crohn's disease.

Option D: The King's College Hospital Criteria is a prognostic tool for patients with acute liver failure (ALF).

questions.text: A 56-year-old diabetic male patient complains of a burning sensation in both legs and episodes of excruciating pain, tingling, and a sensation he describes as "pins and needles." Which of the following drugs is used in the first-line treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
In the given scenario, the patient has painful diabetic neuropathy. Duloxetine is a selective serotonin–norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (SSNRI) and is one of the drugs used in the first-line treatment of painful diabetic neuropathy. 

Painful diabetic neuropathy manifests as a burning, excruciating, stabbing, or intractable type of pain or presents with tingling or numbness. The pathophysiology of this condition is due to primarily metabolic and vascular factors.

Treatment of painful sensory neuropathies:

 First line:

  • Lidoderm 5% patch
  • Tricyclic antidepressants (e.g., amitriptyline, nortriptyline)
  • Gabapentin, Pregabalin
  • Duloxetine

Second line:

  • Carbamazepine
  • Phenytoin
  • Venlafaxine
  • Tramadol

Third line:

  • Mexiletine

Optimal glucose control is considered the cornerstone for the treatment of diabetes and its complications. Intensive glucose control has been shown to prevent the development of peripheral neuropathy.

questions.text: A 51-year-old female is undergoing a clinical assessment for aphasia. Her speech is non-fluent and interrupted by many word-finding pauses. She says, "walk dog", and nods her head when asked if she meant to say, "I want to take the dog for a walk". The comprehension of speech is intact, and the patient knows what she wants to say. Other neurological examination findings are within normal limits. Which area of brain damage can result in such a type of aphasia?

choices.text: Inferior frontal gyrus of the dominant hemisphere
Posterior temporal and parietal lobes, dominant hemisphere
Posterior parietal and temporal lobes, non-dominant hemisphere
Superior surface of the superior temporal gyrus, dominant hemisphere

questions.solution:
The patient described above has Broca’s aphasia (WA). This usually occurs as a result of vascular damage to Broca's motor speech area in the inferior frontal gyrus due to occlusion of the superior division of the middle cerebral artery (MCA).

A lesion in this region leads to motor/Broca's aphasia. Speech is non-fluent and interrupted by many word-finding pauses. The speech is impoverished in function words that contribute to the syntax but is enriched in meaningful nouns and verbs. However, comprehension of speech is intact, and the patient knows what he wants to say.

For example, a patient with Broca's aphasia may say, "walk dog" instead of "I want to take the dog for a walk". Speech therapy in Broca's aphasia is more successful than in Wernicke’s aphasia.

Aphasia is an acquired disorder of language due to damage to the brain. It occurs either secondary to brain injury or degeneration and involves the left cerebral hemisphere to a greater extent. Both written and spoken communication are affected. Audio-visual understanding is also deranged.

There is difficulty in finding words, leading to poorly understood content for the listener. These patients also find it difficult to repeat sentences and name things properly. Aphasia is diagnosed in patients with deficits in the formal aspects of language, such as word-finding, word choice, comprehension, spelling, or grammar.

Many specific aphasic syndromes have been reported. The most common are Broca, Wernicke, conduction, and global aphasias. Other are non-peri-sylvian aphasias that include anomic, transcortical motor, transcortical sensory, and mixed transcortical, sometimes called the isolation of the speech area syndrome.

Wernicke’s aphasia occurs as a result of damage in the posterior temporal and parietal regions, which are supplied by the lower division of the middle cerebral artery.

questions.text: A young man presents with recurrent, excruciating, and stabbing type of left-sided headaches. He has been experiencing at least 1 episode every other day. It typically lasts for  an hour and occurs around the same time everyday. Examination reveals nasal congestion and a watery left eye. Which of the following can be given to manage this acute episode?
questions.solution:
A patient with repetitive brief unilateral, excruciating stabbing headaches, occurring almost at the same time everyday, associated with lacrimation and rhinorrhea most probably has a diagnosis of cluster headache. The acute episodes in this condition can be treated with 100% O2 at 10 -12 L/min. 

High flow oxygen is crucial in the management of an acute attack. The duration of oxygen therapy should last 15 to 20 minutes. Other treatment options for an acute attack of cluster headache include injectable/nasal form of sumatriptan. Noninvasive vagus nerve stimulation (nVNS) is also approved by the FDA for the treatment of acute episodes of cluster headaches.

Cluster headache is a form of primary headache characterized by excruciating recurrent headache, that is unilateral in nature, and typically lasting between 15 to 180 minutes. The important feature of this headache is periodicity. At least one of the daily attacks of pain recurs at the same hour each day. 

It also causes severe, unilateral retroorbital pain with autonomic features, such as unilateral lacrimation, nasal congestion, and conjunctival injection. Occasionally features of Horner's syndrome may be seen.  Patients with cluster headaches are more often smokers with a higher than average alcohol consumption.

The drugs used in the prophylaxis of cluster headaches are verapamil (most common), topiramate, gabapentin, etc.

Other options:

Option A. Verapamil is the drug of choice for the prophylaxis of cluster headaches.

Option C. Lorazepam does not have a role in the management of cluster headaches.

Option D. Indomethacin is used in the management of paroxysmal hemicrania. This condition is characterized by unilateral severe headaches lasting between 2 to 45 minutes and can occur more than 5 times a day. Unlike cluster headache, paroxysmal hemicrania has a very good response to indomethacin.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true about Friedreich's ataxia?

choices.text: Skin lesions represent a common manifestation of this disorder
The molecular defect involves the expansion of a trinucleotide repeat sequence
The onset of symptoms occurs after age 25 years
It is transmitted in an autosomal dominant manner

questions.solution:
Friedreich's ataxia (FA) is a rare genetic disease that occurs due to spinocerebellar degeneration. It is inherited as an autosomal recessive disorder due to a molecular defect on chromosome 9 that involves a GAA trinucleotide repeat expansion.

It is the most common of the autosomal recessive ataxias. There is a loss of large myelinated axons in peripheral nerves, though the unmyelinated fibers in sensory roots and peripheral sensory nerves are spared.

It results in difficulty in walking, loss of sensation in the upper and lower limbs, and impairment of speech. The patients develop ataxia usually before the age of 25 years. Other features include:

  • Progressive dysarthria
  • Bilateral extensor plantar responses
  • Sensory polyneuropathy with absent deep tendon reflexes in the lower extremities.
  • Scoliosis and pes cavus

The patients may also develop certain ECG abnormalities such as like supraventricular tachyarrhythmias secondary to cardiac involvement. Diabetes mellitus is more common and this syndrome is associated with an increased incidence of cancer.

questions.text: A middle-aged man complains of the frequent dropping of handheld things and tripping while walking. On examination, the patient appeared as shown in the image below. Strength is 4/5 in the intrinsic muscles of the hand. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The above clinical scenario and the image showing the patient with frontal balding, and a typical hatchet-faced appearance are suggestive of type 1 myotonic dystrophy.

Myotonic dystrophy is an autosomal dominant disorder. It is caused due to CTG trinucleotide repeat in DMPK gene on chromosome 19. It is mainly of two types: myotonic dystrophy type 1 (DM1), and myotonic dystrophy type 2 (DM2).

Clinically, patients will have a typical hatchet-faced appearance due to wasting of the temporal and masseter muscles. Frontal baldness and a high-arched palate are also seen. 

It is associated with weakness in the distal muscles of the wrist, fingers, and foot. Involvement of the palatal, pharyngeal, and tongue muscles causes dysarthria and dysphagia. Involvement of the diaphragm and intercostal muscles leads to respiratory insufficiency. Proximal muscles remain unaffected.

Diagnosis is mainly clinical. ECG shows conduction abnormalities in the form of first-degree heart block. Electromyography may show myotonia in DM1, however, it is patchy in DM2. Creatine kinase levels in the serum may be normal or mildly elevated.

The histopathological finding of muscle biopsy in both DM1, and DM2, shows internalized nuclei seen in individual muscle fibers, and the presence of several atrophic fibers with pyknotic nuclear clumps.

Treatment is mainly symptomatic. However, mexiletine is indicated for both DM1 and DM2 help in reducing myotonia.

Other options:

Options A and B: Duchenne and Becker muscular dystrophies present with proximal muscle weakness. These are x-linked recessive dystrophies. Therefore, family history would reveal that mainly men in the family are affected.

Option D: In Pompe's disease or acid maltase deficiency is a glycogen storage disease. Affected children present with hypotonia, myocardiopathy, and hepatosplenomegaly. Respiratory muscle weakness leading to ventilatory insufficiency may be a prominent feature.

questions.text: A 58-year-old female was diagnosed with a large pituitary mass on MRI scanning. The presence of high circulating levels of which of the following hormones avoids the need for surgical resection of the pituitary gland?
questions.solution:
Circulating prolactin levels should always be assessed in cases of pituitary adenomas, as the presence of high prolactin levels indicates prolactinoma, which can be treated with dopamine agonists, thereby avoiding unnecessary surgical resection.

Dopamine agonists are first-line therapy in most patients with prolactinoma. Commonly used dopamine agonists include bromocriptine, cabergoline, and quinagolide.

Dopamine agonists reduce serum prolactin concentration and cause a significant reduction in the tumor size after several months of therapy. If the patient has any visual defects due to tumor suppression effects, they tend to improve within a few days after the administration of dopamine agonists.

Prolonged use of ergot-derived dopamine agonists such as bromocriptine and cabergoline may cause fibrotic reactions in the heart due to interaction with 5-HT2B receptors. These effects are mostly seen in patients with Parkinson's disease. Hence, if prolonged treatment is required, then non-ergot agents such as quinagolide are indicated.

In patients who achieve normoprolactinemia and significant reduction of the tumor mass, the dopamine agonist can be withdrawn after two years of therapy.

Note that surgical decompression is usually necessary only when a macroprolactinoma does not respond adequately to dopamine agonist therapy.

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman presents with headache, fatigue, malar rash, and arthralgia. Her blood pressure is 180/100 mmHg. Urinalysis revealed hematuria, proteinuria (4 g/dL), and RBC casts. She has high titers of anti-dsDNA antibodies. A renal biopsy was done, and light microscopy showed sub-endothelial deposits, resembling wire-loop lesions. Findings of immunofluorescence staining are shown below. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in the management of this patient?

choices.text: Hemodialysis and maintenance therapy with azathioprine
Therapeutic plasma exchange and high-dose steroids
Low-dose steroids and azathioprine for 3-6 months
High-dose steroids and mycophenolate mofetil for 2-6 months

questions.solution:
The clinical features and investigation findings are diagnostic of lupus nephritis. The image shows a characteristic full-house pattern of positive staining for all immune reactants. The next best step in the management is to induce remission by administering high-dose steroids, in combination with mycophenolate mofetil or cyclophosphamide for 2-6 months. 

This is followed by maintenance therapy with lower doses of steroids and mycophenolate mofetil or azathioprine. (Option C)

Evaluating the clinical case given in the question:

  • The presence of malar rash and arthralgia is suggestive of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE).
  • Urinalysis shows hematuria (>5 RBCs/HPF), and nephrotic range proteinuria (>3.5 g/dL), RBC casts. These findings, along with the presence of high titers of anti-dsDNA antibodies, are indicative of lupus nephritis.
  • Light microscopic examination of the renal biopsy revealed characteristic 'wire-loop' lesions, which are seen due to sub-endothelial immune complex deposition. The presence of wire-loop lesions is suggestive of diffuse proliferative lupus nephritis (class IV).
  • Further, immunofluorescence staining, as shown in the image, revealed positive staining for all immune reactants (IgG, IgA, IgM, C1q, C3, kappa, and lambda light chain), commonly known as the "full-house" effect, characteristic of lupus nephritis.

Lupus nephritis:

Lupus nephritis is a serious complication of SLE and is seen in about 30-50% of patients with the disease. Renal involvement may be in the form of glomerulonephritis or tubulointerstitial nephritis. Glomerular lesions develop due to the deposition of the circulating immune complexes on the glomerular basement membrane, mesangium, and/or throughout the glomerulus.

Depending on the biopsy findings, lupus nephritis is classified into six classes. The details of the classification by the international society of nephrology are provided in the pearl attached below. 

Therapeutic plasma exchange (Option B):

  • It is indicated in patients with severe lupus nephritis who do not respond to conventional therapy.
  • It is also indicated in patients with lupus nephritis who present with anti-phospholipid antibody syndrome.

20% of patients with lupus nephritis will reach end-stage disease and may require dialysis (Option A) or transplantation.

questions.text: A 42-year-old man presents with acidity and abdominal pain for the past few months, not relieved by taking antacids. Endoscopy revealed prominent gastric folds and ulcers on the second part of the duodenum. Investigations revealed elevated serum gastrin levels and increased basal acid secretion. Which of the following is the next best investigation?

choices.text: Endoscopic ultrasound guided deep gastric biopsy
Blood gastrin levels following secretin administration
Monoclonal antibody-based H. pylori stool antigen test
Double contrast barium study of proximal  GI tract

questions.solution:
The presence of peptic ulcers and poor response to antacids, together with elevated serum gastrin levels and increased basal acid secretion are suggestive of Zollinger-Ellison syndrome. The next best investigation to confirm the diagnosis is to perform a secretin stimulation test.

In normal individuals, the administration of secretin causes no change or a slight decrease in blood gastrin levels. However, in patients with ZE syndrome, the circulating gastrin levels paradoxically increase following secretin administration.

Other investigations include:

  • Tumor localization and staging using a combination of CT and endoscopic ultrasound
  • Radio-labeled somatostatin receptor scintigraphy
  • 68gallium DOTATATE PET scanning

Other options:

Option A: Endoscopic ultrasound-guided deep gastric biopsy is usually done to diagnose infiltrating gastric tumours such as linitis plastica (GLP) and gastric lymphoma.

Options C and D: Monoclonal antibody-based H pylori stool antigen test and double-contrast barium study of proximal GI tract are the tests indicated for the diagnostic evaluation of H. pylori peptic ulcer disease.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic tests in Zollinger Ellison Syndrome

To confirm the diagnosis of ZES,

  • Gastric pH <2.5 and
  • Serum gastrin >1000pg/ml (normal <100pg/ml)

Provocative tests can be done like the secretin stimulation test when the diagnosis is in doubt. An increase in serum gastrin >200pg/ml following an IV bolus of secretin (2U/kg) is diagnostic.

Other tests:

  • BAO >15mEq/h (or >5mEq/h if they have had a procedure for peptic ulcer)
  • BAO: MAO ratio is increased (>0.6)

(BAO=Basal acid output; MAO=Maximal acid output)

For localization

  • Initial investigation - CT or MRI
  • Best investigation - Endoscopic ultrasound
  • If the tumor is not localized - Somatostatin receptor scintigraphy.

questions.text: A 78-year-old male was diagnosed with clostridium difficile infection due to a prolonged course of antibiotics for intraabdominal infection following a ruptured diverticular abscess. He was treated with metronidazole, and diarrhea resolved. After 2-weeks he developed loose, non-bloody stools about six times a day. Stool toxin assay was done, which was again positive for C difficile. He was treated with vancomycin for 10 days with a resolution. 10 days later, he presented with relapsed C difficile infection. Which of the following is the next best step in management?

choices.text: Metronidazole 500 mg 3 times daily for 7-10 days
Vancomycin 125 mg 4 times daily for 7-10 days

questions.solution:
This is a case of recurrent clostridium difficile infection, for which Fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) is recommended. The procedure involves transplantation of stool from a healthy donor, into the patient with the disease by enema or colonoscopy. FMT is increasingly being used to restore a more advantageous gut microbiome profile.

Clostridium difficile infection:

It is the most common antibiotic-associated diarrhea. It is commonly seen in individuals who receive a prolonged antibiotic course, which causes a change in the composition of gastrointestinal microbial flora, leading to colonization of C. difficile.

Clinical features:

  • The majority of the cases (>80%) occur in patients above 65 years of age with comorbidities.
  • The onset is insidious and may occur within 1 - 6 weeks after the initiation of antibiotic treatment.
  • The symptoms include lower abdominal pain with loose watery diarrhea.
  • In some patients, the disease may progress to life-threatening pseudomembranous colitis.

Investigations:

  • Detection of clostridium toxins A or B in the stool.
  • Stool screening is initially done for the detection of glutamate dehydrogenase enzyme (GDH) produced by C. difficile or PCR to detect C. difficile nucleic acid. If the screening is positive, C. difficile toxin ELISA or tissue culture cytotoxicity is usually performed.
  • Sigmoidoscopy reveals characteristic appearance, with erythema, white plaques, or an adherent pseudomembrane.

Management:

  • If the patient is currently prescribed any antibiotics, they should be stopped, and the patient should be isolated.
  • First-line therapy includes immediate cessation of the offending antibiotic along with a 10-day course of oral fidaxomicin for mild cases. Oral vancomycin can also be used, but oral fidaxomicin is preferred as it has a lesser relapse rate.
  • Intravenous immunoglobulin and or glucocorticoids may be administered in patients with most severe disease or those who are unresponsive to the initial therapy.
  • In cases of recurrent C. difficile infection, fecal microbiota transplantation (FMT) is usually done, which helps in restoring the gut microbiome profile.

Related Pearl: Diagnostic criteria for Clostridium difficile infection

 

The diagnosis of CDI is based on a combination of clinical criteria:

1.Diarrhea (≥3 unformed stools per 24 h for ≥2 days) with no other recognized cause      

2.Detection of toxins A or B in the stool by PCR or culture

               or               

 Detection of pseudomembranes in the colon

questions.text: A pathologist received a blood-tinged CSF sample for evaluation. The sample was subjected to centrifugation and the following finding was observed. What is the least likely differential diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given image shows xanthochromatic CSF on centrifugation. This is unlikely with a traumatic tap. A traumatic tap has clear supernatant following CSF centrifugation.

Xanthochromia refers to the yellowish appearance of CSF. In a lumbar puncture, a traumatic tap can be confused with subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH) as both show blood in the drawn CSF sample. In such situations, centrifugation of the sample distinguishes the two.

  • Clear supernatant following CSF centrifugation supports a traumatic tap.
  • Xanthochromatic supernatant suggests SAH.

Xanthochromatic supernatant may be present in the following conditions:

  • In Liver disease, due to elevated bilirubin levels.
  • When CSF protein concentration is elevated.
  • In subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), RBCs are present in the CSF long enough for them to undergo lysis. This releases hemoglobin which is converted to bilirubin, thus staining the CSF yellow.

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding plasma calcium?

choices.text: Ca2+ sensing receptor is a voltage gated ion channel
Albumin bound calcium is physiologically most important
Calcium is mainly absorbed from large intestine

questions.solution:
Acidosis favors the ionization of calcium.

Clinical correlation: 

Hyperventilation by causing alkalosis favors the deionization of calcium without reducing the total calcium levels. Thus, alkalosis can precipitate tetany and laryngospasm in calcium-deficient patients

The ca2+ sensing receptor is a type of G protein-coupled receptor (GPCR). 50% of the Ca2+ is in ionized form and is physiologically most important. Calcium is mainly absorbed from the small intestine.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man presents with acute pain in the chest which radiates to the interscapular region of the back. He is a known hypertensive for the past 10 years. His CT is shown below. Which of the following drug is contraindicated in this patient?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario and the CT image showing double-lumen of the aorta are suggestive of aortic dissection. Isolated use of a direct vasodilator such as hydralazine is contraindicated in acute dissection.

It is because these agents can increase hydraulic shear and worsen the dissection by causing vasodilation without reducing the left ventricular ejection force that continues to weaken the arterial wall. 

Medical therapy for aortic dissection includes beta-blockers and sodium nitroprusside to reduce cardiac contractility and blood pressure. The heart rate is reduced to around 60 bpm and the SBP is lowered to ≤ 120mmHg.

CCBs like verapamil and diltiazem may be used IV if nitroprusside or beta-blockers cannot be employed. Parenteral angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor such as enalaprilat may be considered.

questions.text:
What is the most common pattern of thyroid hormone levels in a patient with sick euthyroid syndrome?
  1. Decreased T3, Normal T4, Normal TSH
  2. Decreased T3 , Decreased T4, Normal TSH
  3. Normal T3, Normal T4, Increased TSH
  4. Normal T3, Increased T4, Normal TSH
questions.solution:
The most common hormone pattern observed in sick euthyroid syndrome (SES) is a decrease in total and unbound T3 levels with normal levels of T4 and TSH. This pattern is called low T3 syndrome.

SES is caused by an acute severe illness in the absence of underlying thyroid disease. T4 to T3 conversion via peripheral deiodination is impaired leading to a fall in T3 corresponding to the severity of illness. There is an adaptive increase in the level of reverse T3 (rT3). 

In very sick patients, there can be a dramatic fall in both total T4 and T3 levels. This pattern is called low T4 syndrome and is associated with a poor prognosis.

questions.text: Management of hyperkalaemia includes all except
questions.solution:
Among the given options, magnesium sulphate has no role in the management of hyperkalemia.

Hyperkalemia is a medical emergency that requires urgent treatment. Even in the absence of ECG changes, patients with plasma K+ concentration ≥6.5 mEq/L should be aggressively managed.

Intravenous calcium gluconate (10 mL of 10% solution) is administered over 2-3 minutes with cardiac monitoring to protect the heart while other measures are taken to correct hyperkalemia. Calcium increases the threshold of action potential thereby reducing excitability. 

Insulin-dextrose infusion is given to shift potassium into cells. The recommended dose is 10 units of regular insulin followed immediately by 50 mL of 50% dextrose. β2-agonists like salbutamol can also be used in conjunction with insulin.

Cation exchange resins, diuretics, and dialysis are used to eliminate potassium. Sodium polystyrene sulfonate is a cation exchange resin that exchanges sodium for potassium in the gastrointestinal tract, increasing fecal excretion of potassium. Newer intestinal potassium binders like patiromer and ZS-9 are preferred due to their lack of intestinal toxicity. Hemodialysis is the most effective method to reduce plasma potassium concentration.

In hypovolemic patients with oliguria, intravenous saline may be beneficial to improve distal delivery of sodium and enhancing renal potassium excretion. Loop and thiazide diuretics can be used in hypervolemic patients with sufficient renal function.
